hotspots.hotspot:
Worker 1: 2 pairs of jeans

The first worker is able to make two pairs of jeans by himself. The total production of jeans is two pairs.

Worker 2: 3 pairs, increases total product to 5

The second worker adds an additional three pairs of jeans. This brings the total production of jeans to five.

Worker 3: 5 pairs, increases total product to 10

Adding a third worker enables all three workers to be more productive due to specialization of labor. The total production of jeans increases to ten pairs. The addition of this worker has doubled production.

Worker 4: 4 pairs, increases total product to 14

The fourth worker makes four more pairs of jeans, bringing the total production to fourteen pairs. Although the fourth worker added four pairs to the total output produced, her contribution was not as great as the previous worker, so we begin to see diminishing returns.

Marginal Product

The additional output produced by adding one more unit of an input

Change in Total Product

The change in total product is calculated by subtracting the first total product from the second total product.

Change in Inputs

The change in inputs usually refers to the change in the number of workers. Usually this number will equal 1. Because dividing by 1 leaves the number the same, the marginal product is usually equal to change in total product, and this divisional step is unnecessary.
